thread.title_full: Get your shovels, another storm on its way - New Brunswick - CBC News

title: Get your shovels, another storm on its way - New Brunswick - CBC News
text:
Get your shovels, another storm on its way 'Hazardous winter conditions are expected' warns Environment Canada as another storm approaches CBC News Posted: Feb 15, 2017 6:21 AM AT Last Updated: Feb 15, 2017 7:43 AM AT Wednesday will be a nice day to play in the snow ahead of another storm which is expected to begin this evening, bringing as much as 30 cm to the south along with gusty winds. Thanks to Jordan Rinehart for this great shot of Reese enjoying the snow. (Submitted by Jordan Rinehart) Related Stories 
Environment Canada has issued a winter storm warning for all of southern and central New Brunswick and for the entire eastern coast, including Bathurst and the Acadian Peninsula. 
The next winter storm is expected to arrive in New Brunswick overnight. 
"Hazardous winter conditions are expected," the national weather service said. "Snow and blowing snow…will spread across southern New Brunswick Wednesday night and persist into Thursday." Keep digging: Monday's blizzard forces more closures into Tuesday 
Winds from the northeast will gust up to 90 km/h in the southeast with total accumulation between 15 and 30 centimetres expected. The highest amounts will be over southeastern regions by Thursday evening. 
The storm is expected to clear from west to east Thursday afternoon and evening with blustery northwest winds remaining for eastern New Brunswick. 
"Storm totals through Thursday appear to be 15 to 25 centimetres for southeastern New Brunswick and Prince Edward Island but 30 centimetres are not out of the question," said Brennan Allen, CBC's meteorologist. 
Elsewhere in New Brunswick, residents can expect 8 to 15 centimetres of snow. Enjoy it while it lasts More snow and strong winds are on the way for New Brunswick on Wednesday night as another storm is expected to dump another 25 cm of the white stuff. (Vanessa Blanch/CBC) 
Temperatures today will be mild compared to the last several days. 
"Expect today to be relatively nice," said Allen. "With partly cloudy skies to a mix of sun and cloud across the Maritimes." 
However, the evening hours will bring increasing cloudiness as the two areas of low pressure will meet. 
"One moving east from Ontario and Quebec, and another moving up the U.S. seaboard will merge just to the south of Nova Scotia and rapidly intensify in the overnight hours, through Thursday morning." 
Allen said the storm will move quickly over eastern Nova Scotia but may slow down as it works its way into the Gulf of St. Lawrence. New Brunswick forecast 
Northern New Brunswick 
Today: It will be partly cloudy with a chance of flurries, light winds and a high of –5 C. 
Tonight: Expect increasing cloudiness and snow beginning by morning. Total accumulations of 15 to 25 cm, except 8 to 15 cm in the northwest. Winds will be from the north at 30 km/h, gusting to 50 km/h with a low of –9 C. 
Thursday: Snow and blowing snow with strong winds and a high near –6 C. 
Fredericton and area 
Today: Expect a mix of sun and cloud with a chance of flurries, light winds and a high of –3 C. 
Tonight: Increasing cloudiness and then snow and blowing snow with total accumulations of 15 to 25 cm expected. Winds will be from the northeast at 30 km/h, gusting to 50 km/h with a low of –7 C. 
Thursday: Snow and blowing snow throughout the day with strong winds and a high near –5 C. 
Southern New Brunswick 
Today: It will be a mix of sun and cloud with a chance of flurries, light winds and a high near –2 C. 
Tonight: Increasing cloudiness on the way, then snow and blowing snow with total accumulations of 15 to 25 cm. Winds will be from the northeast at 40 km/h, gusting to 70 km/h by morning with a low of –6 C. 
Thursday: Snow and blowing snow is expected with strong winds and a high near –3 C.
